item.title: S06E11 - From Mono to Wilderness: Unleashing the Wild Side of .NET in IoT with Bryan Costanich
item.description: Bryan Costanich, founder of Wilderness Labs, takes listeners on a journey into the future of IoT, discussing its potential to revolutionize industries and solve real-world problems. With the ability to enable .NET developers to easily build and maintain hardware, Wilderness Labs' platform offers exciting possibilities for developers. From the importance of microcontrollers to the significance of security in the IoT space, this podcast provides valuable insights into the quiet revolution that is transforming various sectors. Whether you're a developer or simply curious about the world of IoT, the Modern .NET Show is a must-listen resource to stay informed and inspired.

item.title: Figure out who's leaving the company: dump, diff, repeat
item.description: One common element of the larger places where I've worked is that they tend to have a directory service of some sort that keeps track of who's an employee and who isn't. You can learn some interesting things by periodically dumping that list and then running comparisons against the previous dump.

item.title: Why I am moving on from Substack
item.description: I had a Substack where I would occasionally post some things on AI. The vision was to build a following, but I couldn’t execute it. There may be some “blaming the equipment, not the player” here, but from what I have learned, my writing flow feels so much better now: First of all, I think Substack is great. Its mission is clear, and overall, they do a great job executing it (much better than Medium, imo).

item.title: Semantic programming
item.description: I believe we are at the threshold of a new programming paradigm. As the latest advancements in AI make it more accessible and closer to a self-hosted utility, we are entering a world in which developers can articulate what they want to achieve in simple natural language terms. I call this paradigm semantic programming.

item.title: Hacking My Apartment Intercom
item.description: Last week, my fiancée and I moved into a new apartment in New York. Our very first NYC apartment a few years back had an old school buzzer that would ring in the apartment and had the little device on the wall that let us open the door from upstairs.

item.title: Fixing a Chrome + Windows Game Bug
item.description: A few weeks ago I added voice acting into Busty Barrister Barbara. It worked fine, until I tested out a Web build on my Windows PC. The audio sounded terrible, it sounded like it had gaps in it. Interestingly the bug only occured on Google Chrome for Windows. Windows Chrome ❌ Windows Firefox ✅ MacOS Chrome ✅ MacOS Firefox ✅ MacOS Safari ✅ Sadly about 3.22 billion people use Google Chrome for Windows.

item.title: Cascade Inference: Memory Bandwidth Efficient Shared Prefix Batch Decoding
item.description: Many LLM inference tasks involves multiple independent text generation from a shared prefix (prompt), e.g. Self-Consistency, Tree of Thoughts and Skeleton-of-thought. Serving LLMs with common prefix could be memory and time-consuming, especially when common prefix is long and the number of requests is large: a possible use case is long document QA (Figure 1), multiple users interacts with ChatBot with the same document as prompt. While vLLM alleviate the memory issue by only storing one copy of the common prefix. However, it still suffers from the low-efficiency because the default PageAttention implementation do not optimize KV-Cache access to the shared prompt.
item.author: (Zihao Ye (UW), Ruihang Lai (CMU), Bo-Ru Lu (UW), Chien-Yu Lin (UW), Size Zheng (UW & PKU), Lequn Chen (UW), Tianqi Chen (CMU & OctoAI), Luis Ceze (UW & OctoAI))

item.title: Calling System Functions in a JIT
item.description: Writing a practical JIT is somewhat complicated and in fact depends on the assembler; here I present a full example in Haskell. Notably this JIT/assembler is capable of calling procedures in system libraries (i.e. malloc, free)

item.title: Architecting LLM Powered Software | Nasir Shadravan
item.description: The first wave of LLM apps were famously looked down upon as “gpt wrappers”. Single prompt templates generating simple text. But if you’re building an AI first application, you need an AI design approach. And that’s the moat. You combine the engineering approaches to create a new generation of software. A software that is more natural and more human. Or can process human generated knowledge. There is a lot of hype around AI and Large Language Models.

Besides, if you don't provide one, the Microsoft .NET Framework will provide a useless one for you.

item.title: Introducing Sudo for Windows!
item.description: Introducing Sudo for Windows We’re excited to announce the release of Sudo for Windows in Windows 11 Insider Preview Build 26052! Sudo for Windows is a new way for users to run elevated commands directly from an unelevated console session. It is an ergonomic and familiar solution for users who want to elevate a command without having to first open a new elevated console.
